comments.author: Eileen
comments.content: Lentil salad is so great!  I wonder why more people don't eat it in the US?  I am all about lentil vinaigrette, and am super excited to add this salad to my repertoire too. :)

comments.author: Kris
comments.content: Your salad looks lovely! Question for you: are these the kind of lentils one would use to make Indian dal makhani?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Kris - great question. Nope. Dal Makhani is made with urad dal or black gram I believe; those are both rather different than these black lentils, which don't break down when you cook them.

comments.author: Lotte
comments.content: What a beautiful presentation this salad made on the plate, and it is so good.  I did not have shallots but I pulled a couple of onions from my garden and harvested a bowl of yellow volunteer cherry tomatoes.  I was also short on oil and only had olive oil so I cooked thinly sliced onion in batches and followed your guidelines for how to cook and crisp the onion.  wow! Best onions I have ever made.  I had to use white balsamic vinegar but that was actually really good.  I can definitely serve this for guests as a middle course with perhaps a soup as appetizer and a nice dessert.  What are your thoughts on substitutions?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I think your substitutions sound perfect! You figured out what to do with what you have on hand, which is always what I would want folks to do.

comments.author: Fresh local
comments.content:
What is the difference between this caviar lentils and th begula lentils? From your I gradient list they seem to be the same thing, but on chefshop.com there are both items, just a bit confusing! Does the "caviar lentil" specifically from the Palouse? 

Much thanks.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I think it is just branding, they are the same or very similar.
